commit_list.message:
Cumae Display: better context management.

This change brings along quite a bit of refactoring of the Cumae layer.
Most of the changes are non-functional as they are a refinement of
existing code.

A display context has been introduced with a better and more flexible
way to initialize the display. This should make supporting new display
variants a little bit easier.

One of the difficulties that have been found is about the delay function
that has been 'hacked' to be usable at runtime. It'll need to be
reviewed as it might waste quite a lot of cycles for simple delays.

Supporting new displays should be rather easy now; to do that:

1. Add the relevant information in the cumae/header/config.h
2. Fix the cm_display_type_e enum to include the new display
3. Provide the boilerplate code in cm_display_get_default_context
4. Remove the display check throughout the code to include the new type.
5. Test and fix
6. Fix and test
7. Test and test
8. And test again
commit_list.repo_description: Tiny pseudo-RTOS for AVR MCUs, currently powering SBuCa

commit_list.message:
Cumae Display: staged update.

It's now possible to update the display frames in stages. This minimizes
the occurance of ghosting effects.
The algorithm needs to be furtherly optimized to be faster but we're on
the right track here as the thing is now finally usable.

:-)
commit_list.repo_description: Tiny pseudo-RTOS for AVR MCUs, currently powering SBuCa

commit_list.message: Removing a useless target in Makefile.in.

commit_list.message:
Cumae Display: frame management.

Most of the work to produce this change was about coming up with a
trivial way to generate correctly aligned frame data.

Introducing: Cumae Framegen :)

Framegen is a Python script that generates correctly aligned C data
structures ready to be integrated into a Cumae app.

The script has already been integrated in the Cumae build system
(basically few neat Makefiles:)) in such a way that it will generate
frame data for whatever PBM file it finds in the gfx/ directory.

A C header file will be generated for each PBM file found in the gfx/
directory. The include path for such files will be <frames/FILENAME.h>.
commit_list.repo_description: Tiny pseudo-RTOS for AVR MCUs, currently powering SBuCa

commit_list.message:
Cumae Display support for SBuCa B1.

SBuCa lives. This commit brings along very important changes.
The highlights are:

* EPD/G2 display has been brought up
* SPI primitives are working
* Minimal test frames for the display
* Makefile.in: libcumae.a target is now elegant.:)

Some minor tweak here and there, of course, including some versioning
attempt that is not really making me too much happy but, all in all,
it's pretty simple to fix in the future.

commit_list.message:
New Cumae features: Permanent Data and UUID.

A simple permanent data struct has been introduced in the base Cumae
code. This is mainly meant to be used to differentiate devices.
It's also gonna be used as starting point for some sort of "preference"
system that I'm thinking to implement.

The first use case is with UUIDs: there are a couple of interesting new
Makefile targets. Issuing "make unique" will:

1. Initially create a new empty binary file
2. The binfile will then be filled with the relevant:
    a. Cumae version information
    b. a UUID
3. After that, the binfile will be burnt on the device EEPROM

Cumae will read the content of the EEPROM and will show the relevant
information at boot time.

The struct cm_permanent_data_s will be extensible.;)
commit_list.repo_description: Tiny pseudo-RTOS for AVR MCUs, currently powering SBuCa

commit_list.message:
LED mgmt, low-power mode and new GFX data.

This squashed commit brings along some long-needed change about the way
the status LED is handled, along with a simple - but very effective -
low power mode that kicks in after around 60 seconds from the last user
activity.

In order to achieve that, the prescaler has been set to /64 and given
that the clock is currently set to 12MHz, the Timer1 overflows every 3~
seconds.

When that happens, a "stand-by" frame is pushed on the G2 so that users
can enjoy a nice QR code that points to this repo.:)
commit_list.repo_description: Tiny pseudo-RTOS for AVR MCUs, currently powering SBuCa

commit_list.message:
Integrating libemotly in mainline.

This change brings the first integration of libemotly with mainline. As
a way to keep things clear, these are the changes:

* libemotly is added (EmotlyService.swift)
* Two dependencies have been added to the tree: Alamofire and SwiftyJSON
* Carthage is being used to manage the dependencies
* CI (Travis) has been updated accordingly

In order to keep up, contributors have to:

1. Install Homebrew
2. Install Carthage from Homebrew
3. Bootstrap the build from the root (where Cartfile is), this means
   running the command carthage --bootstrap
4. Open the project normally.

commit_list.message:
TestRunner: simplified and less noisy.

TestRunner now discovers new test cases automatically, also some minor
changes:

1. all the test cases have been renamed to test_SOMETHING.py; this is
needed for the test cases to be discovered and run automatically

2. there were several cases of raw 'assert' in the test cases: they've
been changed to more relevant self.assertSomething() methods from the
unittest package

3. PEP8 is less noisy too: when everything checks out it'll just stay
shut, as we like it.:)

commit_list.message:
PWA: huge refactoring, sorting.

This is YAFHC aimed to restructure the overall architecture of the PWA
in order to better address future needs.

The most important changes are:

1. new PWA architecture; the Emotly service has been abstracted in a
reusable component (emotly-sa.js)
2. Emotlies coming from the service are now sorted
3. Moods are sorted too
4. Relative dates for emotlies in home
5. The non-PWA part of the app has been revised to also include a very
clear 'login' link.

commit_list.message:
First version of the PWA client.

In this early version we set up all the needed machinery to serve the
Progressive WebApp client. Most of the URLs had to be changed to be put
within the scope of the app.

When this change lands in production the clients [1] will be able to add
Emotly on the home screen; the app will be kinda usable also when the
user is offline or with bad data connection.

A lot of field testing will be necessary to define all the corner cases.

[1] ATM the only platform to support (almost) all the features we make
use of is Android/Chrome.
commit_list.repo_description: Public instance of the Emotly service

commit_list.message:
WebApp Manifest served in /.

The WebApp Manifest was ignored since it landed in production; it turned
out that it had to be served from the root for the UA to consider it.

We're fixing this here by mocking the /manifest.json URL by serving
whatever is in static/app/manifest.json.

Probably this is a bug of the implementer as nothing like this has been
found in the spec [1]. We'll have to revisit this issue in the future,
therefore a relevant FIXME has been added.

[1] https://w3c.github.io/manifest/
commit_list.repo_description: Public instance of the Emotly service

commit_list.message:
Mega refactoring with substantial induced pain.

This is a megachange (for the project): we're getting back Giovanni's
idea to have separate static/templates directory. It was a good idea.

Probably the most important changes are:

1. Every controller is a blueprint (thanks to Giovanni, again:))

This will prove a very flexible approach as soon as new controllers will
be added to the main app.

2. A app-wide configuration file that will ease the pain: it uses common
defaults so everything can be run without specifying anything among the
env vars.

All the previous env vars still apply and they do override the default
parameters.
